title: Thursday, 24th January 2019
bodyHTML:
11:09 am

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc. Feels like we're struggling a bit for an overarching theme right now.

BE11:13am

Everybody knows that time is running out on both Brexit and US-China trade. But the conventional view in Davos remains that “reason” will prevail and that the most economically-destructive scenarios will be averted.

However, a clear lesson of recent years is that there is a large and growing gap between what Davos regards as rational and what the voters in the west regard as reasonable. If that gap did not exist, Hillary Clinton would now be US president and Britain still would be firmly anchored inside the EU.

FY18 revenue +39% to £236m (Jeff +31% to £223.5m, cons £227m) with UK +52% (Jeff +40%), US +21% (Jeff +19%) and Europe 24% (Jeff +21%). The Board expects FY results to be comfortably ahead of Board expectations. We continue to view FEVR as one of the most attractive growth stories in European beverages; valuation at 38.5x 2020 PE is not expensive for the growth given the potential for premium mixers internationally.

Curious As patisserie Valerie struggles, which chains are going to benefit from them not being there?

BE11:20am

We see FEVR as a unique asset that offers a leveraged play on premiumisation trends in spirits in a sub-category where there is a disconnect between premium spirits and mixers. Whilst we see a potential hiatus in newsflow as UK normalises and US accelerates, recent de-rating offers an entry point into one of the most attractive growth stories in European beverages. The shares are currently trading at 38.5x 2020 PE.

BE11:22am

Fever-Tree's trading statement only provides commentary on revenue but given strong end to the year we expect some operating leverage on overheads and would expect slightly better performance on operating profit margins than we are currently forecasting (32.1% EBITDA margin). We expect mid single digit increase to consensus. Shares trade on 35x FY20 PE.

As the UK growth rate matures, investor attention has increasingly focused on the trajectory of the US business. We believe that the successful transition of the US in-house and the distribution agreement with Southern Glazer's Wine and Spirits means that it has a strong platform from which to exploit the substantial growth opportunity in the USA. At this stage profit upgrades of c.4% reflect the top-line beat. We re-iterate our Buy rating and increase our TP from 3,450p to 3,600p to reflect upgrades.

BE11:27am

The consensus had already moved down to this level though, with the downgrades we shared here last week re overpaying for Wagamama helping that process. And with guidance unchanged, there's not a lot new to say really.

BE11:27am

Peel Hunt:

11:27 am
BE11:27am

We are cutting our PBT forecast from £52.0m to £51.0m (since 15 January, consensus has fallen from £51.9m to £51.0m), on which basis average EBIT/outlet fell by almost 15% (on top of 2017’s 20% decline). Given these underlying trends, high cost pressures, structural challenges and high leverage in the business, the 7.2x EV/EBITDA rating is high enough, in our view.

Tom Dalgleish So today it's cakes, sugar water, eateries. Add in pubs, Mike Ashley, DEB and we could wind it up
BE11:27am

2018E earnings should fall by c12% and no earnings growth is expected in 2019E, despite forecasts assuming all expansion and synergy targets are maintained, while retaining Wagamama LFL sales growth, turning around the retail/leisure park estate and slowing the pace of cost inflation at Wagamama.

rusty When I was in the Prop Trading world, I got to listen to many arguments between the desk head and one of his trainees about whether or not TA was BS. Fun times.
BE11:28am

And Barclays.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Post close statement from RTN reveals LFLs of -2%. This compares with LFLs -2.2% after 42 weeks, so there has been a modest improvement in trend (implied at -1.2% in the last 10 weeks, assuming equal weighting). Pubs and concessions are said to have traded well, with Leisure seeing “improved momentum”, albeit if pubs and concessions are in positive territory, Leisure LFLs must still be in decline. The PBT outcome for 2018 is said to be “in line with current market expectations”. Bloomberg PBT consensus is £51.2m vs Barclays £51.4m. 21 new pubs have been opened (albeit 15 of these were acquired), and 21 concession sites were opened. Regarding the Wagamama deal, this was completed on 24th December, and Wagamama “continued to trade well over the festive period”. The bond report for Wagamama in Q2 outlined strong LFL sales growth of 12%, an improvement from 8.5% in Q1, but perhaps more importantly an improvement in margins in Q2 (EBITDA margins +50 bps to 16.4%). There is no change to synergy comments or guidance: “we look forward to delivering the benefits of the acquisition”, and no specific guidance comment about FY19. For the “old” business, Barclays’ forecasts assume EBIT of £56.7m vs £54m in FY18, assuming 0.4% LFL sales growth and EBIT margins -20bps. 2018 saw a number of downgrades to consensus forecasts at RTN, so this “in line” statement is mildly encouraging. That said, the key drivers of the investment case from here are the integration of Wagamama, where management need to balance maintaining the strong growth in the core business, as well as delivering c£22m of synergies (including site conversions), to justify the elevated headline multiple on the deal. Note: Our PT is still struck on a pre-rights issue basis, and as a consequence we do not include our valuation multiples in this note.

John63 who was taking which position?
BE11:29am

(@Tom: feel free to start your own live daily markets coverage service if this one doesn't match your requirements.)

A sale of (say) 40% in CTIL would therefore generate proceeds of c.€0.3bn-€0.77bn each.

SGT is more comprehensive (disruptive) than initially envisioned? 1H cash conversion slump is to be reversed, but a bigger ST concern. What could be missed is the overtaking US operation: bigger, and significantly faster growing (20%) than appreciated. PT down to 242p (275p), but remain Buy.

11:48 am

A WC outflow of ~£9m combines with higher tax and the final Fox/acqn payments (the latter known) to drive a ~£15m increase in net debt. ND itself remains comfortable, but the cash conversion slump to 33% (72% 1H18, 90% FY18) will likely generate the greatest concern and questions for the new CFO. The outlook meets this head on with a goal of reversing the WC movement in 2H which will be a focus for the next figures.

BE11:49am

We suspect the market still thinks of NCC as a UK-driven, and perhaps then EU-biased business (given the larger and more problematic/news generating acquisitions in the UK and EU). However the new geographic split of the formerly under-disclosed consulting (assurance) division, which is most welcome, reveals that the US overtook the UK (in sales by destination) and US consulting grew at 20% and US escrow at 10% - both highly impressive and ahead of industry levels.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

But back to Jefferies.

BE11:53am

A leadership problem, or a deeper structural and cultural one? The surprise retirement of CEO Rakesh Kapoor crystallises long-brewing anxieties around RB's predicament. There are strong runners and riders for the role aplenty. But this is a challenge beyond mere fresh legs. The unique RB pay for performance model, so powerful for so long, is now under pressure, laying bare the fact that RB has the weakest culture and workstyle ratings in the peer group.

Soundbuy *aviation
BE11:54am

Mr Deboo's always worth reading. For one thing, he writes in English. Here are the four headings.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Challenge 1: A growing stalemate in Health. The timing suggests that the loss of Pfizer to GSK might just have been the straw that broke Kapoor's back. Not only does it stalemate RB strategically, it also cuts off a vital source of fresh innovation. That leaves RB's Health Relief portfolio reliant on under-pressure Mucinex and a yeoman infantry of Nurofen, Strepsils and Gaviscon fast running out of marching space.
Challenge 2: Maxed-out margins, with the risk of a re-set. RB has been a 20-year rocketship that now earns the highest, or close to the highest, margins in its respective peer groups. But the forces of profit gravity must come into play eventually. Now feels like it might be that moment. Lower growth in Health is spoiling the mix equation, with no further lever to pull in SG&A, where RB has the lowest ratio in the industry.
Challenge 3: Spin or sale of HyHo no slam dunk. An exit from the to-be-separated 'HyHo' business at a premium would be a get out of jail free card and the most obvious challenge to our case. But we are mindful of the contingencies and probabilities. Full separation won't be achieved until mid-2020. A spin-out offers an uncertain upside. Amongst strategic buyers, we don't think ULVR is interested and HyHo would be a big stretch for HEN3. That leaves Private Equity.

BE11:55am

Challenge 4: Downside risk to 2019 consensus. We downgrade FY19 EPS by 3.5% and go 6% below consensus, reflecting an expectation of a further year of sub-3% sales growth, flat margins, plus the stronger £. The immediate risk to numbers, and a key catalyst, is the weak cold and flu season in the US, compounded by Mucinex share loss. A mere whisper of that took 4% off the shares yesterday. Relative to which we think there is further still to go. We downgrade target valuation to 11.4x EBITDA/14.3x PER to reflect a lower growth outlook, with downside risk to expectations.

FATDAZ re towers and telcos just had a look at American Tower over layed on to AT&T over three years Tower has missivelly out performed AT&T different markets ie US not UK but my hunch is towers and infrastructure are the place to be going forward as well

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

FY08 results are what they are.

BE12:04pm

Here's Shore to summarise.

BE12:04pm

Revenue +125% and adjusted EBITDA loss slightly ahead of expectations. 2019 outlook in line for c75% revenue growth before impact of proposed placing to raise £100m to accelerate global growth, though EBITDA losses likely to materially widen.

The robotic process automation software and services specialist reports its full year results for FY2018 (October year-end), confirming strong revenue momentum slightly ahead of expectations (+125% to £55.2m versus prior FY +155% and Cons £54.5m), adjusted EBITDA losses on continued investment (loss £21.6m versus prior FY loss of £8.3m and Cons loss £22.8m), with the company prioritising investment for scale and growth. Free cash outflow of £6.5m versus prior FY inflow £4.0m is considerably lower than EBITDA loss due to modest working capital requirements, low capex/sales and annual billings from customers that benefit cash flow more than the P&L. Net cash stood at £50.5m (ShoreCap £49m).

Sitting behind the revenue performance was significant growth in the number of software deals with new and existing customers. As flagged in the Nov. 2018 trading update, the total number of software deals secured during year was 1,359 (FY17: 609), up by 123%, consisting of 528 customer additions (FY17: 324), 723 upsells across 310 customers (FY17: 264 upsells across 131 customers) and 108 renewals (2017: 21). At the end of 2018, the total customer base stood at 992 (2017: 477), up from 700 at the half year.

The Board is said to be “encouraged” by the exit monthly recurring revenue generated by the sales momentum in the ﬁnancial year ended 31 October 2018, and as a result, expects revenue for the 2019 ﬁnancial year to be in line with the improved expectations outlined in its trading update issued on the 27th November 2018. Current consensus for FY2019 revenue is £86.2m (ShoreCap £96.3m).

The Group has this morning also launched a process to raise up to £100m (before expenses) in an equity placing (c13% dilution), carried out by way of an accelerated book build. We expect broadly half of the of the funds to be deployed across sales & marketing, R&D and customer success over the next 12 -24 months with £50m retained for the balance sheet. With the top-line impact lagging this investment, we expect our EBITDA loss assumption for FY2019F to go up from the current £29m.

At 1179p, EV/Sales of c8.4x (FY2019F) is at a trough level since the group listed in March 2016 and an c80% discount to peak. Additionally, the prevailing market cap is at a c70% discount to the mean of the recent private-equity backed valuations of its two closest RPA (Robotic Process Automation) peers, namely UiPath and Automation Anywhere. We therefore see the shares as both rationally and attractively valued with good upside potential over the medium term driven by strong equity rating compression.
